bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 29, 1900

div1.p: Reed relates his plans for Keewaydin concerning the garden, a summer house, and a new house. He has seen their son, Lawrence, and reports that he is well, but he as yet has no commission.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 29, 1900
div1.opener:
Camp Columbia,
Quemados, Cuba,
July 29, 1900
No. 26,
Sunday forenoon.
My precious wifie;
div1.p:
I have
a little time at my dispos-
al to write a few lines to
my darling girls- I have
had callers all the morning
& am expecting Darboy
to come out & spend the
day with me- So that, if
I don't write now, I won't
get any chance till to-night.
My! but I had good luck
yesterday- Three letters
from the fairest of the fair,
one dated July 20th; another
22nd, & still a third July 24th.
The one of the 20th, I should
have had last Wednesday-
But it just missed the boat
& so was delayed in its ar-
rival until Saturday-
And such sweet, interest-
ing and cheerful letters they
were! I could have told,
after the first few lines,
that it had rained at
Keewaydin and that the weather
was cooler! What a relief
it must have been to
my precious children and to
dear Aunt Jane to be rid
of such abominably unen-
durable weather! And all
the time we in Cuba were
enjoying the cooling showers
and sea-breezes! Now, I
must stop to read again your
dear letter of the 20th- Well,
if the weather was so hot that
Miss Meadows & Miss Motts
passed the julep by, all I've
got to say is that it must
have been very warm in those
parts! I am so glad that
you put the boughs over the little
maples and that they are still
alive & growing -- of course,
it must have been very
trying to the Evergreens-
I should not have been
surprised to hear that they
had all succumbed- Never
mind about the strawberries-
I am afraid that runners
made in such hot weather
wouldn't make good plants.
We can buy better ones
very cheap -- enough to en-
tirely fill the whole bed,
so that next season my
sweet babies can just
revel in the luscious fruit!
I told you, Miss Farmer-lady,
that the grass was safe-
Kentucky blue is very te-
nacious of existence and
hard to kill after one good
season. Won't you enjoy
the blackberries now? That
soaking rain will be
just what they need- My!
if they could only last till
august 8th or 10th! I should
just like to taste one or two-
But the peaches won't be
gone! That is something
delightful to look forward to!
Here I had to stop my letter
for a while- Dear Darboy
Came out soon after and took
dinner with us- I enjoyed
his visit very much- He looks
well & hearty, but not as
fleshy as when you saw
him last- He expects his
appointment any day,
& hopes that he can get it
by the time my transport
leaves- I heard this afternoon
that the Rawlins would
sail august 2nd, Wednes (Thursday)
but this is not positive-
I hope that she will leave
by Wednesday the 1st. I
read your letters to Darboy
& he enjoyed them very much,
He sends much love to Mother & Sister
Monday Morning, 30th July- Good
morning, Miss Fatty, how are
you this beautiful, cool Cuban
morning? Still asleep? Oh!
Get up and pick some of those
delicious rasp black berries
for your breakfast! But
don't get any of those “big
yellow fat bugs” mixed up
with them! He! He! Your
precious letter of July 22nd
was so interesting- It did
me good to hear of the way
things were beginning to grow
at dear Keewaydin- I could
see you and dear Aunt Jane
sitting up on the top stone
wall of the garden, while You
read about the delightful sum-
mer climate of Cuba! I must
hurry up & come so as to see
those pretty poppies- Don't
let them all bloom before I
get there- I think your sug-
gestion as to the clematis
at the end of the arbor
will be too pretty- That
drawing was immense
lovie, dear! So you and Auntie
and aunt Annie think that the ter-
raced garden is a success-
I thought that that it would
please the artistic eye
as soon as the vegetables
got to growing well- You
must send auntie some veg-
etables, when you have them
to spare. Hurrhah! for that
road that Johnnie Moore
built! So it's smooth and
hard is it? Well when Johnnie
Moore tackles a road, or any
thing else, its pretty apt to be
well done! Give him my kindest
regards- He must get the mason
of whom he spoke to build the
pillars when he gets there- of
course that summer-house must
be of Stone! Didn't I tell you
so, you sweet, fat stone-tosser!
Johnnie Moore will build it!
Talk to him about it! Don't tell
me any more about “Carrie freez-
ing ice-Cream”! I don't want
to hear about it! So the nice
young bean caught you napping?
Well, that was a pickle!! and
the two young ladies trying to
straighten out their back hair!
of course we must build a house.
Didn't I tell you so? Save the
money? Aren't we doing that
very thing, you precious mink?
Put some chickens in that pan
& begin to fatten them for me!
Don't forget the cabbages- Boo! Boo!
Love to aunt Jane & Helen- Kisses & love
for my precious girls-
